etymologies: Middle English: from Old French, from Latin basis ‘base, pedestal’, from Greek

definitions: the lowest part or edge of something, especially the part on which it rests or is supported

examples.text: she sat down at the base of a tree

definitions: the part of a column between the shaft and pedestal or pavement.
the end at which a part or organ is attached to the trunk or main part

examples.text: a shoot is produced at the base of the stem

definitions: a line or surface on which a figure is regarded as standing
a line of known length used in triangulation.
the lowest part of a shield.
a conceptual structure or entity on which something draws or depends
something used as a foundation or starting point for further work; a basis

examples.text: uses existing data as the base for the study

definitions: a group of people regarded as supporting an organization, for example by buying its products
a place used as a center of operations by the armed forces or others; a headquarters

examples.text: the corporal headed back to base

definitions: the main place where a person works or stays

examples.text: she makes the studio her base

definitions: a main or important element or ingredient to which other things are added

examples.text: soaps with a vegetable oil base

definitions: a substance such as water or oil into which a pigment is mixed to form paint.
a substance used as a foundation for makeup

examples.text: her makeup artist works with base, eye makeup, and lipstick

definitions: a substance capable of reacting with an acid to form a salt and water, or (more broadly) of accepting or neutralizing hydrogen ions.
a purine or pyrimidine group in a nucleotide or nucleic acid.
the middle part of a bipolar transistor, separating the emitter from the collector.
the root or stem of a word or a derivative.
the uninflected form of a verb.
a number used as the basis of a numeration scale.
a number in terms of which other numbers are expressed as logarithms.
shortDefinitions: number against which others are expressed

definitions: one of the four stations that must be reached in turn to score a run.
used to refer to progressive levels of sexual intimacy

examples.text: she and her boyfriend got to second base

shortDefinitions: used to refer to progressive levels of sexual intimacy

definitions: have as the foundation for (something); use as a point from which (something) can develop

examples.text: the film is based on a novel by Pat Conroy
inaccurate conclusions based on incomplete facts

definitions: situate as the center of operations

examples.text: a research program based at the University of Arizona

etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French bas, from medieval Latin bassus ‘short’ (found in classical Latin as a cognomen). Early senses included ‘low, short’ and ‘of inferior quality’; from the latter arose a sense ‘low in the social scale’, and hence (mid 16th century) ‘reprehensibly cowardly, selfish, or mean’

definitions: (of a person or a person's actions or feelings) without moral principles; ignoble

examples.text: the electorate's baser instincts of greed and selfishness
we hope his motives are nothing so base as money

definitions: denoting or befitting a person of low social class.
shortDefinitions: denoting or befitting person of low social class

definitions: (of coins or other articles) not made of precious metal

examples.text: the basest coins in the purse were made in the seventh century AD

shortDefinitions: (of coins or other articles) not made of precious metal
